learning_outcomes.description: Acquire a critical understanding of the role of technologies in geopolitics and global governance.
Demonstrate the ability to debate topics related to the interactions between technologies and multi-level actors.
Apply tools and concepts of geopolitical analysis to current affairs involving emerging technologies.
Advance original arguments using the geopolitical frameworks and empirical evidence to assess the consequences of emerging technologies and practices of global governance.
Communicate persuasively in verbal and written genres to academic and professional audiences.

assessments.task_description:
• 1 mark per session from Week 2 to Week 13.
  • Assessment will be based on in-class contributions (not just attendance), including participation in activities, group work, and seminar discussions.
  • Instructions and rubrics will be made available to students on Blackboard.
  • In case of seminar absence, please contact the course coordinator to discuss your circumstances.
  • This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.

assessments.task_description:
• Online Submission via Turnitin
  • In Week 3 and Week 11, students are required to submit tasks designed to support essay and exam preparation.
  • Each task is worth 4% of the final grade.
  • These tasks may include identifying primary and secondary sources and critically analysing the required readings.
  • Instructions and rubrics will be made available to students on Blackboard.
  • This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance. A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Assignments for this course will be submitted electronically via Blackboard and using Turnitin.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
• Online Submission via Turnitin
  • Word count: 2,500 words (+/- 10% leeway), excluding notes and bibliography
  • Essay Questions and instructions will be made available to students on Blackboard.
  • This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance. A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Assignments for this course will be submitted electronically via Blackboard and using Turnitin.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
• In-person exam during the Examination Period
  • Students will be given multiple questions and are required to choose ONE to answer.
  • The exam type is an Essay Exam. Students will be asked to write a long answer for the selected question in essay form, with introductory and concluding paragraphs to ensure a logical structure. Exam tips for Essay Exams are available at https://my.uq.edu.au/information-and-services/student-support/study-skills-and-learning-advice/study-skills-and-learning-advice-overview/exam-tips
  • Sample questions will be shared with students.
  • Instructions and rubrics will be made available to students on Blackboard.
  • This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 1. Introduction

  • Welcome
  • Key Questions at the Intersection of Technology, Geopolitics, and Governance
  • Status: Where does technology currently stand?
  • Strategy: What are the responses to geopolitics?
  • Stakeholders: Whose roles matter?
  • Course Overview
  • Teaching Staff

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L05
